steps.title: The Cloudify Console
steps.content: This tour reviews the areas of the Cloudify Console. Let's get started...

steps.title: Console pages
steps.content: Here you can click on a page to work with a specific group of Cloudify actions, such as Local Blueprints or Deployments. Administrators can customize the pages to help streamline your work.

steps.title: Widgets on the pages
steps.content: On each page is a set of widgets. Each widget lets you do a specific Cloudify action. Widgets are grouped on the page so that you can easily access related actions. Administrators can also customize the widgets on each page to meet your needs.

steps.title: System status
steps.content: Here you can quickly review the status of the Cloudify services to see if there is anything that needs attention.

steps.title: Switch to other tenants
steps.content: If you can access multiple tenants on the Cloudify Manager, here you can select the tenant that you want to work on.

steps.title: Get help
steps.content: If you need more information about using the Console or the Cloudify Manager, here you can find link to documentation.

steps.title: User menu
steps.content: The user menu here gives you access to customizing pages and page templates if your user roles allow those actions. It is also where you logout.

steps.title: Next steps...
steps.content: Now that you know the structure of the console, check out other tours about working with the Cloudify Console.

steps.title: The Cloudify Console Dashboard
steps.content: The Cloudify Console dashboard contains widgets that do basic actions and show the status of selected tenant. Let's see what the widgets are...

steps.title: Tenant resource load
steps.content: Here you can see how many blueprints, deployments, plugins are available, and you can see how many nodes and executions are running currently. These statistics can indicate the load on the tenant.

steps.title: Resource actions
steps.content: You can upload blueprints, create deployments and upload plugins straight from the dashboard.

steps.title: Execution filters
steps.content: Here you can filter the executions and events to show only those that are related to a specific blueprint or deployment.

steps.title: Executions
steps.content: These are the executions that the tenant is implementing currently.

steps.title: Check out another tour
steps.content: Now that you know how to use the dashboard, check out another tour to see what else you can do with the Cloudify Console.

steps.title: Cloudify Manager Resources
steps.content: Before you start working with blueprints and deployments, you must setup the resources that the blueprints use. Let's get started...

steps.title: Managing tenants and users
steps.content: Cloudify Manager use tenants for data and user segregation. The Cloudify Manager is installed with a default-tenant. If you need other tenants, make sure you define the tenants that you need on your manager before you start using the manager.
onNextRedirectTo: You need to have Tenants Management widget present on current page to proceed to the next step.

steps.title: Add tenants
steps.content: Add tenants to the manager. The tenants let you separate sets of plugins, secrets, blueprints and deployments for each tenant. For more information about sharing resources between tenants, see resource visibility in the documenation.

steps.title: Add user groups
steps.content: You can create user groups and assign them to tenants with roles. Users in a group inherit the roles of the group.

steps.title: Add users
steps.content: You can add users and assign them to tenants with specific roles. If you import users and groups from an external authentication source, you can only assign user groups to tenants.

steps.title: System Resources
steps.content: After you setup your tenants and users, go to System Resources to setup the plugins and secrets that you need for your blueprints.
onNextRedirectTo: You need to have Plugins widget present on current page to proceed to the next step.

steps.title: Plugins
steps.content: Plugins let your blueprints integrate with third-party services and run operations. The plugins required by a blueprint are specified in the blueprint yaml file. You must upload the plugins to the tenant before you upload the blueprint to the tenant.

steps.title: Upload a plugin
steps.content: When you know which plugins your blueprints need, upload them to the tenant.

steps.title: Create secrets
steps.content:
Blueprints use the get_secret function to get values from the encrypted secrets store. That way you do not have to store sensitive information in plain text in the blueprint. Create the secrets that your blueprints need.
For information about hidden secrets, see the documentation.

steps.title: Check out another tour
steps.content: Now that you know how to setup your manager resources, check out other help resources to see what else you can do with the Cloudify Console.

steps.title: Get working with Cloudify
steps.content: After you setup your manager resources, it's time to use Cloudify to deploy an application. Let's get started...

steps.title: Cloudify Catalog
steps.content: Cloudify catalog contains prepared blueprints and plugins that you can use right out of the box. By default the bluprints are taken from the cloudify-examples repository. You can point the widget to your own repository of blueprints.
onNextRedirectTo: You need to have Blueprints Catalog widget present on current page with at least one blueprint to proceed to the next step.

steps.title: Upload a Blueprint
steps.content: When you click Upload, the blueprint is uploaded to your Cloudify Manager. The blueprint is available in Local Blueprints, where you can also upload other blueprints.
onNextRedirectTo: You need to have Blueprints widget present on current page with at least one blueprint to proceed to the next step.

steps.title: Deploy Blueprint
steps.content: Click Deploy to turn the blueprint into a deployment with specific inputs. You can deploy multiple times to spin up multiple environments.
onNextRedirectTo: You need to have Deployments widget present on current page with at least one deployment to proceed to the next step.

steps.title: Install the Deployment
steps.content: In the deployment menu, you can run executions on the deployment. Open the menu and select the Install execution.

steps.title: Deployment Status
steps.content: You can see the status of the nodes in the deployment as the deployment is installed. You can click on a deployment to see more details about it, including topology, nodes, inputs and outputs.
onNextRedirectTo: You need to have Executions widget present on current page to proceed to the next step.

steps.title: Executions Status
steps.content: In the Dashboard you can see the executions that are currently running, including the processes that are installing the deployment.

steps.title: Check out another tour
steps.content: Now that you know how to deploy an application, you can go to the day-two processes tour to review the maintenance tasks that you can do on a deployment.

steps.title: Manage your deployments
steps.content: After you deploy some applications, you need to monitor them and sometimes you need to run executions on them. Let's see how to do that...
onNextRedirectTo: You need to have Deployments widget present on current page with at least one deployment to proceed to the next step.

steps.title: Deployments
steps.content: All of the deployed applications are listed on the deployments page. In the menu for the deployment you can execute workflows on the deployment, including heal and scale.

steps.title: Update a Deployment
steps.content:
You can click on a deployment to execute workflows available for that deployment.
Click on the Update Deployment button in a deployment.
Notice that you can change the blueprint, change the inputs, and you can explicitly list the nodes to update. The Deployment Events/Logs in the deployment show the events on the deployment as they are happening.

steps.title: Filter the Deployments
steps.content: You can use the filters to show deployments for specific blueprints or sites.

steps.title: Customize Pages
steps.content: In the user menu, administrators can enable Edit Mode and add widgets to pages from the widgets catalog.

steps.title: Custom Templates
steps.content: Administrators can also select template management and define the pages that are shown to users when they login.

steps.title: More Information
steps.content: Now that you know how to deploy an application, check out other help resources to see what else you can do with the Cloudify Console.
